page.lettertext:
fol.328r
May it please your good L. I have s
e
t w
t
this l
re
e abbreviat of a muster, w
c
was lately taken of
e
c
o
panies,
t
are under
S
r
Francis Vere
. They have bin
many wayes diminished by
e service of this s
o
mer, as
will be writt
e
to your L. by S
r
Francis himself: but by
nothing so much, as by their c
u
ming away, sins warning
was giv
e
for their going into
France
. For w
c
I am
suaded,
at they will be many fewer, at their c
o
ming
to
Flushing
, and have tak
e
therefore order,
at they
shall at their arrival be mustered againe. S
r
Francis Vere
and
e Captaines are gone thither already, and attend
e c
o
ming of
e c
o
panies: w
c
have bin stopped these 12
dayes, through
e roughnes of
e winde, w
c
is against
th
e
at this p
nt
: w
c
I thinke in like maner is
e stay
of my l
res
,
at have bin writt
e
in
t
behalf. I
have signified in my last, what order I have tak
e
for supply of
e c
o
panies
at are appointed out of Bergh
e
.
As yet I doe not know, how
e
States of Zeland
doe
digest it. But I make full acco
u
t,
t
they will
use but small delay. Having sent to
e c
a
pe
for
S
r
Nicholas Parkers
officers to
p
pare his horseband for
Britaine
, as yet I have receaved no answear againe,
but S
r
Nicholas himself in c
o
ming out of
England
, hath
passed by
e Hage, and I have signified unto him her
M
ts
pleasure: who is also ready to
fourme as much
as is re
q
red. He doeth onely request to have some
time for his souldiers, having bin in
e field for 5
moneth together, to repare their furniture. He
alleageth besides
t
many of his troupe being Dutche,
and divers of them maried (as there are in like
maner in
S
r
John Poleis
c
o
pany) he shall hardly be
able to induce th
e
to goe w
t
him: and those
at shall
fol.328v
be wonne, will be craving of time, to make their
visi
o
.
And where I have
suaded him, to exchange w
t
S
r
John
Poley, and to take some others in
e places of those
t
are maried and are loth to depart, he affirmeth
t
e most of
e horses, w
c
are of his c
o
pany, are bought
by himself, as he thinkes S
r
John Poley will
p
tend
e very
same, and
t
in c
o
ming to exchange, they shall hardly
come to agree, in
e valuing of their horses one
against an other. Moreover there is no im
p
st
appointed to be given to his c
o
pany, to make
vision
for their victuals and all other necessaries, as there
is
u
to
e footm
e
. For nothing hath bin written
to my self about it, and
e officer of
e T
re
r hath
receaved no order. Lastly it is some grief to
S
r
Nicholas Parker,
t
having allwayes c
o
manded under
S
r
Francis Vere, he should fall in his credit to a lower
degree, and having no charge be c
o
manded by an
other, wh
o
he thinketh he must serve but for a
garde of assur
a
ce. I have answeared these
objections as well as I could, and I have writt
e
to
e
Councel
, and to
Co
u
t Maurice
, to graunt him a
pasport to come unto Berghen, to put his troupe in
order, and to make their
vision. I have
also
mised, if neede shall re
q
re, to be an indiffer
e
[t]
arbiter betweene him and S
r
Poley, in the passing of
their horses fr
o
one to an other:
at I trust I sha[ll]
p
vent all occasion of c
o
tention. Heere [ys]
nothing yet c
o
cluded, for any further imploym
t
[of]
their forces in
e field: albeit they have bin long [in]
c
o
sult
a
on about it. their opinions, I heare, [are]
very divers therein. Some doe hold it be[st]
to send
e soldiours for a time to refreshe themse[lves]
fol.329r
in their garrisons. Others would proceede to the
taking of
Grolle
and
Oldenzeel,
and other small
townes in
e
Twente
and
Drente
. There are also
some
t
would endevour to blocke up all
e passages
t
laide into
Groeningh
e
, w
c
they make an easie mater.
It is proposed by some others,
t
they should give an
attempt up
o
e towne of
Bolduke
: or make a bridge
to passe
e Rhine by Sgravenert, and so by skowring
t
cost, to hinder
e returne of
e Enemies forces, w
c
are thought to be as yet, w
t
e chiefest of their str
e
gth
about Oldenzeel: attending, as it seemeth, w
at
we will
resolve. The state is somewhat troubled w
t
Co
u
t Maurices courses. For although it be so
t
he
hath spedded very happely in this enterprise of
Coe-
voerd
e
, yet
e expense of time and of mony hath bin
excessive, and might have bin lessened in many respects
if he would have obeyed
e states resolution. For
w
c
I finde by their speeches,
t
if he had missed of
taking
e place, they would have shortened his authorite
in sundry speciall pointes: as it may be
adv
e
ture
they intend to doe as yet. For sins the winning of
e Castel, he hath c
o
mitted
e custody of it to the
states of Frisland
: against an expresse charge to the
c
o
trary fr
o
e Councel of Estate, and directly, as
ey
say, against his othe as governour of
Overyssel
,
to whome, as all m
e
affirme, it ought in all reas
o
to have bin delivered. Wherat not onely they, but
e rest of
e Provinces doe greatly repine, reputing it
an act both inconsiderat and daungerous. For
besides
e putting of variance betweene
e two Pro-
vinces, w
c
have lived of late, for other like occasions in
very badde neighbourhood, it will set
e Province of
fol.329v
Frise
in so great a securitie in regard of
e Enemy
that such as are acquainted w
t
e humour of
e people,
doe thinke assuredly
t
being m
e
full of stomacke,
opposit in their dealings, over sparing in their charges,
and in all their
ceedings very willfully bent, they will
not for heerafter be c
o
tributours to
e warres, but in
such a
portion as they list themselves. I am
half of opinion, and many men thinke it certaine,
at
up
o
this departure of
e Englishe c
o
panies, and
e c
o
treis
p
tence,
at
e Contract is brok
e
, they will not long c
o
tinue
this Councel of Estate, but take some other forme of
governm
t
. Howbeit because they stande in some hope,
t
her M
tie
doth but purpose to w
t
draw th
e
for a time,
they may happely differ their intended innovation.
Moreover I am
suaded,
t
they would be well c
o
tented
to make a motion to her M
tie
or to hearken rather
to her M
tie
if it should in her behalf be
posed
u
to
th
e
,
t
they might heerafter be assisted, w
t
the
im
p
st of some mony, and w
t
a great deale lesser
s
u
me th
e
is spent by her Hig
nes
at this p
nt
: or is some
suche other sort, as both her M
tie
may be eased in
e
burd
e
of her charges, and
e contrey relieved w
t
a
c
o
petent aide. Which I write unto your L. but onely
by c
o
jecture, not having bin moved in
e mater by any.
And as touching
e dissolving of
e Councel of Estate,
considering how farre their autoritie is abridged, it [can]
be nothing
p
judicial to any purpose of her M
tie
[. For]
where
e Treaty doth ordaine,
at
e governour g
na
l [for]
her M
tie
and
e Councel of Estate shall order all aff[aires]
appertening to
e warres, and to
e governm
t
of [the]
c
o
trey, her M
tie
undoubtedly by
t
course might recea[ve,]
being duely put in practise, a very singular bene[fit]
fol.330r
But there is nothing now
formed of all
t
was
c
o
tracted, but onely in an outward formal shewe,
e States assuming to themselves
e direction of every
action. I receave at this inst
a
t a l
re
fr
o
Co
u
t Maurice, wherin is signified
u
to me
t
he
hath retained
e horseband of S
r
Nicholas Parker, upon
hope
t
her M
tie
being informed of
e great disc
o
moditie
w
c
e c
o
trey shall receave, through
e losse of his c
o
pany,
whereof he prayeth me earnestly to advertise her
Hig
nes
she will change her forsaid purpose. I have
s
e
t heere w
t
all
e copie of his l
re
: and by one of
e
Councel, w
c
came fr
o
Swoll
u
to the Hage, I have bin
instantly moved in
e name of all
e rest, to
e same
effect as
e Co
u
t hath written. Wherupon
cosidering w
t
my self, how much
e c
o
trey is grieved
already,
t
the footm
e
are w
t
drawen, I have thought it
very meete for her M
ts
better service, to give them
some c
o
tent, and to stay
e urging of
e mater, till I
heare once againe how her M
tie
is affected: w
c
I am
also c
o
strained to attend of necessitie, for
t
the c
o
pany
till th
e
, will be hardly put in readines. Howbeit
as your L. may
ceave by
e writing of
e Co
u
t, if
her M
tie
in her purpose, to have
e c
o
pany away, c
o
tinue
still resolut, there will be no resist
a
ce.
There are also s
e
t unto me, fr
o
e Councel of
E state 3 intercepted Englishe l
re
s, of w
c
I have sent
you
e originals heerew
t
. They were tak
e
fr
o
one
t
was coming fr
o
Collen
, w
t
divers other Spanishe
and Italian l
re
s, of w
c
one was fr
o
Rome
fr
o
e
Spanishe Ambassadour
, and was writt
e
in ciphers, and
is c
o
mitted to one
t
will travell to decifer it: and
fol.330v
likewise those wordes,
t
are writt
e
in cipher in the
English l
re
s. Whatsoever shall be found shall
be signified to your L. The rest of
e l
re
s in
Itali
a
and Spanishe c
o
tened litle mater, but of the
c
o
ming to
Paris
of
e
Duke of Ferraria
, of the
election towardes of
e Lieguers Kinge, and of cartels
gone abroade betwene
Parma
and
M
a
tua
, and the
Marquis of Guasto
. There was one of Coll
e
am
o
g
e rest,
t
had writt
e
divers l
re
s to
Anwerp
and
Brussels,
w
t
out putting to his name, and used those
wordes, w
c
I send your L. in a schedule, in 3 of his l
re
s,
w
c
me thinkes may import, as if they looked out of
England
, for some newes extraordinarie.
And
thus I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage. 7
ber
21 1592.
